summary_points.title: Green Opening for Indian Benchmarks
summary_points.summary: Nifty50 and BSE Sensex kicked off Thursday’s session firmly in positive territory, with Nifty around the 25,100 mark and Sensex up over 150 points. By 9:16 AM, Nifty50 was trading at 25,094.95 (up 0.18%) while Sensex stood at 82,033.46 (up 0.21%), reflecting broad-based buying interest in early deals.

summary_points.title: Five-Day Winning Streak Extends
summary_points.summary: The domestic equity market notched its fifth straight session of gains, with Sensex climbing 213.45 points (0.26%) to 81,857.84 and Nifty50 rising 69.90 points (0.28%) to close at 25,050.55. Investors continued to build on the earlier four-day rally, pushing key indices higher on sustained momentum.

summary_points.title: Technical Indicators Signal Further Upside
summary_points.summary: Chart patterns are pointing to continued strength, as Sensex formed a bullish daily candle and an intraday uptrend continuation formation. These technical signals suggest that the market could sustain its upward trajectory in the near term, barring fresh negative triggers.

summary_points.title: Mixed Global Cues Create Flat-to-Lower Bias
summary_points.summary: Asian markets traded mixed and US equities ended mostly lower after the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes, dragging Gift Nifty into a modest premium of about 2 points from Nifty futures. These uneven global cues point to a cautious start, with Indian benchmarks expected to open flat or slightly lower.

summary_points.title: Government Policy and Consumption Drive Optimism
summary_points.summary: Market analysts remain upbeat on the near-term outlook, citing recent government policy initiatives and a pickup in consumer demand as key catalysts. Policy support measures are expected to sustain corporate earnings visibility and bolster overall investor confidence.

summary_points.title: Sectoral Relief and Institutional Flows Bolster Confidence
summary_points.summary: Positive momentum is further underpinned by sector-specific relief measures and robust institutional flows into equities. These factors are aiding market activity across key sectors and lending additional support to the rally.

top_performers.explanation: IT stocks led the rally with Infosys up 3.78% and TCS up 2.64%, reflecting strong quarterly outlooks and ongoing digital‐transformation spends.
FMCG stocks saw broad‐based buying on the back of resilient consumer sentiment and healthy rural demand.
Realty names contributed meaningfully to gains amid an ongoing upcycle and positive housing market dynamics.

underperformers.explanation: US tech stocks endured selling pressure after the Fed minutes, dragging down global technology indices.
Most Asian markets traded lower, reflecting regional growth concerns and dampening sentiment.
Metals and mining stocks were absent from domestic gains, likely feeling the impact of mixed global growth cues.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s market advance was driven by robust institutional flows and continued policy tailwinds, as investors cheered bold government reforms ranging from sector‐specific relief measures to ongoing GST rationalization and fiscal support, all underpinned by a surprisingly benign 1.55% retail inflation reading that rekindles talk of an imminent RBI rate cut. While global cues remained mixed—with Asian bourses flitting between gains and losses and US tech stocks under pressure—domestic confidence held firm, propelling heavyweights Infosys (+3.78%) and TCS (+2.64%) higher and lifting FMCG, realty and auto stocks on the back of sustained consumption momentum and a resurgent real estate cycle.
